ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I felt that I gained a great deal of knowledge in taking this course. Galois theory was an exceptionally interesting subject and I gained much more insight into field extensions and the symmetries between roots of polynomials. This was the the most engaging and fun math course I've taken thus far. Moreover, I felt that through the problem sets I developed much stronger proof writing skills and critical thinking skills as I was forced to delve very deeply into the weeds of the concepts we'd studied in order to understand and then solve a problem.
I learned field and Galois theory, surprisingly enough.  And Miki was teaching, so I learned it very, very well.
Learned Galois Theory
I learned a lot about Galois theory and also got a much better intuition for why lots of things in group theory were important.
Main theorems and ideas of galois theory, improved proof writing and problem solving abilities
Galois groups, field automorphisms, finite fields, cyclotomic polynomials.
You get pretty good at galois theory
Generally speaking, learned about field extensions and Galois groups. Covered roughly all of Stewart's Galois Theory.
Knowledge of galois theory
I learned to become a better mathematician by improving my proof techniques and obviously learned Galois Theory (which is a beautiful subject btw, everyone should take it)

Learned Galois and Field Theory. Specifically, field extensions, constructions, main thm of galois theory, normal and seperable functions, splitting fields, how to field galois groups of polynomials (esp cubic and quartic), gal groups of finite fields, and more.
Learning about field extensions and using Galois Theory to study polynomials.
We learned the fundamentals of Galois theory. Learned about field extensions, splitting fields, Galois groups, etc

Learned about Galois theory/fields - in particular how we can relate fields to groups (which makes it easier to think about fields, at least a bit). Cool things we learned as part of this included: why there's no general formula for roots of degree 5+ polynomials, what n-gons are constructible using ruler and compass (and why we can't trisect an angle), and other cool stuff. Practiced proof writing and problem solving skills.
It's a Galois theory course. You learn Galois theory, plus a few applications (ruler/compass constructability, solubility of polynomials by radicals). It's a good course. You should take it.

I learned how the symmetries of roots of polynomials impact our abilities to solve them, through the tools of field extensions and the Fundamental Theorem of Galois Theory (which creates a correspondence between subfields and groups), with applications to Euclidean constructions and solving the quintic
Field extensions, finite fields, Galois correspondence, constructions, roots of polynomials, applications

We learned the foundations of Galois Theory and some related topics. Namely, we learned about extensions (Galois and otherwise), normality and separability, constructibility of numbers, finite fields, solvability of polynomials by radicals, etc. My problem solving skills and mathematical maturity increased considerably.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Overall the course was extremely well taught and the problem sets were extremely engaging. At times, however, I did feel that the course went a bit slowly and felt I could have had a better experience had the pace gone quicker giving us more time to discuss the applications of Galois theory.

The course is fantastic: lectures are clear, meticulously planned, and engaging; psets are of a reasonable difficulty and reinforce class concepts excellently; exams are fairly written and straightforward tests of understanding; Miki and our TA were both excellent, and there's a huge support network for students.  If you want to see what committed teaching looks like, take any course with Miki - it astonishes me every time.  Maybe there are weaknesses, but I can't find them.
Great course! Very organized and Miki is amazing. She made the content seem very interesting.

One of the best things about this course is the psets.  They really give you a wide variety of problems to practice working with the concepts and weren't too easy or hard.  At the end of the day, psets are how you learn in a math class, so good psets translate to lots of learning.

Great course! The material was presented well to build understanding as we went, like how theorems were explained thoroughly before proofs were given. Problem sets were a good level of difficulty, built upon material covered in class, and were helpful to solidify knowledge.
Strengths: High engagement, lectures clear, Miki is a great instructor
miki is a great professor and she does a great job with the class
Miki is fantastic--she's super clear at explaining concepts, very encouraging, and cares an incredible amount about her students learning. The course material also happens to be very pretty.
I think this was a very well organized course. It was very hard, but the instructors put in the work to have corresponding supports

NO WEAKNESSES

Strengths: Miki is absolutely a gem of an instructor (literally FLAWLESS) and the content itself is incredibly interesting
This class is very difficult and abstract and covers a lot of material. However it was taught my Miki so if one put in enough effort, it was possible to wrap your head around the material.
This was a great course. The material was engaging, the teaching was great, the work was satisfying. I wouldn't change anything.

The instructor - Miki - was definitely a strength, as was our ULA. Take this class if Miki's teaching it - Miki does a good job of scaffolding new material, affirming students while keeping the course rigorous, building community, the list goes on. In general the course was very good as a result - all the material was delivered effectively and the course ran very smoothly. The only weaknesses of this course are more general weaknesses of math courses - e.g., at least in this year, it had timed exams (and timed math exams are kinda silly from a design standpoint), and most of the course was lecture-style, neither of which are necessarily weaknesses per se, but there could be more experimentation with the course format and tailoring it to help all students learn.
Mostly I just need to improve my own sleep schedule (which deteriorated in the second half of the semester).

The course was very cohesive and well structured. The homework assignments were very useful for consolidating one's understanding of the topics introduced in class, and the pre class assignments ensured that we reviewed concepts continuously throughout the semester instead of just before the exam. Some of the homework problems were quite challenging, but there were many office hours to get assistance. I do not have any complaints, other than that sometimes the lectures moved quite quickly, although that might have been necessary to get through all of the material.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I absolutely would recommend this course to another student! Galois theory is such a fascinating subject and a really beautiful way to apply techniques from abstract algebra to understand something as simple as symmetries of roots of polynomials. The applications of Galois theory are also astounding and getting to see how we can use this theory to examine topics like the solvability of polynomials by radicals is absolutely fascinating.
Take this course.  If you want to see what committed teaching looks like, take any course with Miki - it astonishes me every time.  And the material is pretty cool, too.
Yes would highly recommend, Galois Theory is such a cool and powerful area of math and Miki teaches the content very well.
Yes.  Galois theory is beautiful, and Miki is an excellent teacher.
Yes! For any math major, it's well taught and the material is super interesting!
This class is great!
Yes, if you like algebra.
Definitely. It is very hard, but very fun. If you enjoyed 350, you'll probably enjoy 370 even more!
yes, if you took 350 then should take this class
Yes, a very rewarding math course that is taught extremely well.
Yes, take it! Miki is amazing and you wont regret taking this class.
Yes! For students in the math major, take the algebra courses! They're great
YES YES YES. Miki makes the class so good; she's a fantastic lecturer and she always makes sure we all understand the content before proceeding
If you are a math major interested in the algebra path, then take this class. Dont take this class if you are a casual enjoyer of math.
Yes, but only for math majors. Abstract algebra also isn't for everyone, but if you like 350, definitely take this course.

If you're interested in more algebra, this course is a very fun course. - I also personally found it more engaging and interesting than abstract algebra, since it's less of a 'toolkit' course and has more direction in proving cool results.
Yes, absolutely.

Definitely, assuming they have the right background.

(In general, I am a big proponent of learning things out-of-order and trying to learn topics you don't think you're ready for yet... for self-study. For classes with work and deadlines, I think it should be pretty linear.)
Yes, if you enjoyed Math 350!

YES YES you should ABSOLUTELY take this class, especially if Miki is teaching. Miki is the best lecturer I've ever had -- in math or otherwise -- and never failed to make the content engaging. The way she ran the class was wonderfully designed to facilitate student learning, and it always felt like she had our best interests at heart. Her psets are challenging and engaging, her tests are very fair, and she's very receptive to student feedback. And learning Galois theory is SO rewarding. The theory is beautiful, and the payoffs are incredible (proofs of Fundamental Theorem of Algebra!! proofs that not all quintics are solvable by radicals!! learning about what can be constructed with a ruler and compass!!). This class seriously resparked my love for math, and I wish everyone could take it.

I would recommend the course to anyone who enjoyed MATH 350 and would like to see more algebra (especially if the course is taught by Miki). The material is very interesting/ pretty, and the course was organized very well. But I would recommend to be prepared to put in quite a bit of work, as lectures move quite quickly at times and some homework problems can be quite time consuming. I think it would be a great experience to take any course with Miki - she really cares about her students and puts in a lot of effort into teaching, which may not be very common in the math department.
